posts.name: UFUK
posts.cooked: Can I mount a motor with bent sheet metal directly to the bellypan? I want to use this for low-torque applications like roller motors. My main goal is to make the center of gravity (CG) lower. What are the advantages and disadvantages of using bent sheet metal for motor mounting? Additionally, instead of using one bent part, using two bent parts. How does this affect strength-to-weight ratio? Is it usable for high-torque applications, such as shown in these examples?
I think it could work, though having another plate to support the other end of the shaft might alleviate stress on the overall load. For high-torque applications, extra shaft support is essential.

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: This seems perfectly fine for low torque applications. I’m a bit concerned about high torque applications if it’s mounted directly to the bellypan, as it could flex and bend upward due to the force applied, depending on how well the bellypan is supported in that area.

The issue is less shaft bending than the plate bending. Reinforcing the setup correctly involves bending a flange on the side and attaching it to the bottom or welding the corner to create a rigid part.

posts.name: UFUK
posts.cooked: I think I will use bolts instead of welding. Because welding requires good technique.

posts.name: UFUK
posts.cooked: I asked this question because of bellypan flexing. A riveting bellypan with a support profile featuring a consistent 1-inch gap across its entire length—will this be sufficient?

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
For low-torque applications, it is feasible though not my top choice. I prefer using box tubing for added rigidity, which may require cutting pockets for chains belts or gears to pass through.

That said, this isn’t the worst solution I’ve encountered. The double-stacked setup mentioned earlier is intriguing, but more details about the load type and its direction relative to the mounting bracket would be helpful.

Regarding your query about the bellypan flexing issue, I’m curious about the specifics. Could you clarify how thick the bellypan is and whether it has any additional bracing beyond the frame’s perimeter? Typically, we reinforce the chassis further and attach components to it for better stiffness.

posts.name: UFUK
posts.cooked: Thank you for your answer. Bellypan 3mm aluminium and just 4 frame tubes and 2 support tubes. Totally its 6 aluminium tubes on the chassis.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked: For 3mm aluminum plus two supports, you'll be fine for low-load applications mounted directly to the pan. The material offers minimal flex since we use 1/16" (1.5mm) aluminum, which remains quite rigid when properly supported. If feasible, adding a gusset or another point of contact (like the frame or support tubes) could enhance stability. However, the current setup may still work effectively without additional braces.

For our climber gearbox (high forces) this year, we mounted it to the bellypan and a gusset from a poorly supported 2x1 (shown green). I believe the gearbox & bellypan portion was fine the entire season, @credard correct me if I'm wrong, but the gusset supporting our climber uprights got completely mangled.

posts.name: Chris Redard
posts.cooked: I believe the gearbox and bellypan parts were fine the whole season.

posts.name: Josh
posts.cooked: I don't think there's much cause for worry. Hex shafts are commonly used for various applications, often accompanied by gearbox housings that include mounting holes. While I'm more concerned about sheet metal vibrations causing potential damage over time, in most cases, such setups shouldn't pose significant issues. However, overall, it shouldn't be problematic, particularly for low-torque roller applications. If concerned about deformation, consider reinforcing with an extra scab plate underneath.
